A brave military canine who unfortunately had to sacrifice her entire front limb while ridding a Taliban base during a patrol in Afghanistan, has found a new dwelling with a man whom she rescued. After struggling for two years to adopt her, Staf Sgt Julian McDonald of the US Army was finally able to bring home Layka, a four-year-old Belgian Malinois, to his residence in Columbus, Ohio this week. Sgt. and Layka were on their eighth military tour overseas together. McDonald was shot four times at close range by an enemy fighter carrying an AK-47 in the year 2012. To view the video, continue scrolling downwards. The U.S. Army Staff Sergeant is a member of an excellent team. In 2012, Layka (right), a 4-year-old Belgian Malinois, saved Julian McDonald's (left) life in Afghanistan, and as a result, he brought her to live with him in Columbus, Ohio. Even though Layka was wounded, she managed to finish the mission along with her team, and got her injuries treated once she reached the safe area. Layka and the son of McDonald's, Liam, have developed a strong friendship and spend their time playing together every day. During an emergency surgery, her fellow soldiers quickly brought her back to the operating room and her leg was amputated in order to save her comrades. Sgt. is extremely grateful to her for the courageous and unselfish act she displayed during the combat. McDonald made the decision to have her come and stay with his young family at home. Sgt. expressed that he became aware of his obligation to look after her, in the same way she looked after him. ABC News received a statement from McDonald. I clearly had an obligation to save her life as she had previously saved mine. Layka, despite losing her right leg, has found a secure new home and has also been awarded a medal of honor as a tribute to her courage. Although Layka has been trained to attack enemy soldiers, she is gentle with McDonald's children, and they have developed a close friendship quickly. During his eighth military tour in Afghanistan, McDonald worked with Lyka to clear an enemy compound when they were shot at by a man. McDonald informed ABC that Layka adjusted promptly to living in a non-military environment and developed a close bond with his son Liam. McDonald says that heshe was moved to tears due to her excitement. Without her, I wouldn't be alive and able to return to my family. According to McDonald, Layka will always remain significant to him. At any particular moment, the United States Armed Forces utilize over 500 dogs across the globe. A small number of people die every year while in combat.

The expected protein secretion systems of Frankia sp. The sizes of these organisms are quite small and they have only a limited number of hydrolases, which may indicate that they have adapted to living in a symbiotic manner. The absence of consistently preserved enzymes that break down secreted polysaccharides in all three Frankia genomes indicates that degrading polysaccharides in the plant cell wall is not necessarily essential for root infection, or that this breakdown may differ between different strains. Our hypothesis is that Frankia bacteria have a strategy of minimizing the secretion of enzymes that degrade polysaccharides, in order to prevent triggering host defense responses. The enzymes present in the central Frankia secretome, such as esterases, lipases, and proteases, can potentially aid in the penetration of hyphae through the cell wall, the liberation of carbon sources, and the alteration of chemical signals. The essential secreted proteins also consist of Frankia-related hypothetical proteins and extracellular solute-binding proteins, which could facilitate the actinorhizal symbiosis.

Is "2001: A Space Odyssey" a sermon? A record of the development of the human race? A study of mankind's unsuccessful efforts to improve technology which ultimately lead to its own destruction by technology? Does it concern the delicate equilibrium between time and space? What could be learned from evolution? Could it be that the movie Kubrick created was simply a display of impressive visual effects, intended to demonstrate the vast potential of cinema and reveal to us the fact that images are much more influential than language? All these things are encompassed within 2001: A Space Odyssey. The film is highly open to interpretation, and the process of analyzing and talking about its ambiguous plot structure and happenings is arguably more enjoyable than simply watching it. The reason for intentionally leaving the meaning of Kubrick's extraordinary classic, 2001: A Space Odyssey, open to discussion was to maintain its appeal, complexity, and cinematic value. If Kubrick had explained its meaning, the film could have lost a significant part of its charm and attraction, and it would not have been ranked 22 on AFI's list of the greatest 100 films ever made. Additionally, the film was nominated for four Academy Awards in Director, Original Screenplay, Art Direction, and Visual Effects categories and won the award for Visual Effects. Personally, I consider it my 21st favorite film. Only the technical ingenuity would remain and it is definitely praiseworthy as every opportunity deserves a thorough examination. There is a sufficient amount of time available. The movie 2001 evokes a sense of poignant nostalgia but also has a calm and dispassionate quality. However, the emotional distance and leisurely pace are a fitting homage to the singular visual experience. "2001: A Space Odyssey" commences with prehistoric apes who evolve from scavengers to tool-using hunters after coming across a colossal monolith in their desert abode. The film then skips ahead several thousand years with an iconic jump-cut shot of a bone being thrown into the air, transforming into a satellite. The narrative shifts to space where astronauts have found a comparable object on the Moon. The plot follows a crew of space travelers as they pursue the monolith's signal, all while contending with their deceitful computer, HAL, who attempts to undermine the mission and murder the team. Eventually, the last surviving member is hurled through time and space, accompanied by a kaleidoscope of vivid colors that may have triggered epileptic seizures among hippies. The character undergoes a metamorphosis and is reborn as a "Star-child" before the credits roll. The film's most ironic scene, the destruction of HAL, stands in stark contrast to the pacing and emotional detachment exhibited throughout. It is a peculiarly moving moment as HAL sings a beautiful melody, while the crew's last explorer switches off the machine amidst the reverential glow of red light that Kubrick often uses as a recurring theme. Everything about Kubrick's masterpiece is brilliant. Another remarkable feature is the unforgettable tone of HAL, portrayed by Douglas Rain in a composed but somewhat ominous way. Additionally, Kubrick's wise reliance on imagery to drive the film means that the actors are given only mundane and unimportant lines. "The movie 2001 will always be a mystery and a proof of a cinema's strongest aspect, the visuals, as it features the well-known phrase "Open the pod bay doors HAL," satellites moving to unconventional music in their orbit and a mesmerizing scene of the earth slowly uncovering the bright sun amid the sound of victorious horns." The source of this content is attributed to one of the most renowned and accomplished film directors in history. The director was known for his distinct perspective and creative style which truly remained his own. In the movie "2001: A Space Odyssey," the command "HAL, open the pod bay doors" was given with a perfect score of 10 out of 10.

You are in luck this month because all of our models are on sale! it is a perfect time to buy a new car since it's the end of the year. Person1: That's fantastic to hear! I've been thinking about purchasing a car that is more fuel-efficient. Can you please tell me what car models you currently have in stock? Person2: We offer a diverse selection of vehicles that are fuel-efficient and hybrid. Examples include our compact cars such as the Honda Civic and Toyota Corolla, which have excellent gas mileage. Additionally, if you are looking for a hybrid vehicle, we have the Toyota Prius and Honda Insight available. Person1: Can you provide me with additional information about the features of the Toyota Prius? I've received positive feedback about the car. Person2: Certainly! The Toyota Prius is widely recognized for its remarkable gas mileage, reaching as high as 58 miles per gallon within city limits and 53 miles per gallon on highways. Additionally, it offers a roomy interior, state-of-the-art safety functions, and the convenience of integrating with both Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. Person1: How much would it cost me to buy a Toyota Prius? That sounds great! Person2: If you take advantage of our year-end sale and trade in your old vehicle, you could save a lot of money on a new Toyota Prius, which typically start at 24000. Can you provide me with an approximation of how much my trade-in is worth? Person2: Certainly! To provide you with an exact evaluation, we have to examine your Ford Pinto. However, considering the age and state of your vehicle, you could anticipate a trade-in worth between 1,000 to 1,500. Once our team examines your car, we will be able to give you a more precise estimate. Person1: That seems reasonable. I agree, let's proceed with it. Person2: Great news! Our team will begin examining your vehicle shortly, while at the same time, we can commence the documentation process for your brand new Toyota Prius. You will be driving back home in your eco-friendly car in a jiffy!

A highly-respected senior doctor has tested negative for the deadly Ebola virusafter being placed in isolation at a hospital. Doctor John Parker was taken to Westmead Hospital in Sydney's west for treatment about midday on Saturday after he had developed symptoms of a influenza-like illness. The humanitarian doctor from Sunshine Coast in Queensland had been working at an Australian-run Ebola treatment clinic in Sierra Leone since November last year, Nine News reports. Scroll down for video . Doctor John Parker (centre) has tested negative for the deadly Ebola virus after returning from West Africa . The humanitarian doctor was taken to Westmead Hospital on Saturday morning after falling ill . The aid worker, who has more than 20 years experience as a GP, returned to Sydney on Friday where he stayed at an airport hotel before falling ill about 7am on Saturday. NSW Health has confirmed Dr Parker does not have Ebola and that no further testing for the virus is required at this stage. 'NSW Health can confirm tests undertaken today by Westmead Hospital's Emerging Infections and Biohazard Response Unit laboratory have returned negative for Ebola virus disease,' a spokesman told Nine News. The humanitarian doctor had been working at an Ebola treatment clinic in Sierra Leone since November . Doctors are seen covered from head to toe as they assess Dr Parker for the deadly Ebola virus . The World Health Organisation estimated more than 10,000 people have died from the deadly virus . Dr Parker's employer, Aspen Medical confirmed that he has 'followed protocol and notified authorities as a precaution'. 'A senior member of our team has noticed a slight increase in temperature after returning from Sierra Leone,' the statement read. The World Health Organisation estimated more than 10,000 people have died from the deadly virus in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone.

A successful aging strategy based on psychology can forecast the quality of life in seniors to come. The strategy emphasizes elements such as mindset, ability to bounce back, positive outlook, mental abilities, and personal satisfaction that have a significant impact on how effectively an elderly person adjusts to aging and retains a satisfying lifestyle. A number of researches have indicated that senior citizens who uphold a favorable outlook, participate in mentally challenging tasks, and proficiently handle stress and emotions typically enjoy an improved standard of living. Moreover, the capacity of an elderly person to age gracefully depends on their physical and mental wellbeing, and it is essential to focus on psychological aspects to enhance their general health. According to the psychological approach, it is crucial to sustain a sense of direction, cultivate solid social ties, and participate in significant undertakings throughout the aging phase. Older adults can strive to improve their future life quality and achieve a satisfying, robust, and self-reliant lifestyle by implementing this method.

These data demonstrate that apoptosis is an major contributor to neuronal cell death in the early course of diabetic retinopathy (DR). The upregulation of EpoR may be a compensatory response of retinal cells and tissue to diabetic stresses. The EPOEpoR system as a maintenance-survival mechanism of retinal neurons responds to the insults of early diabetes other than ischemia. The protective function of EPOEpoR at the least acts through the EpoR-mediated ERK pathway. Exogenous EPO administration by intravitreal injection in early diabetes may prevent retinal cell death and protect the BRB function. Therefore, this is a novel approach for treatment of early DR.

Police have dramatically arrested a 27-year-old man who tried to flee the area after officers found a woman's body in the boot of the car he was driving. The man ran into bushland after police stopped a blue Hyundai Getz car on the Bermagui to Tathra Road in the Bega Valley, on the far south coast of NSW, just after 8.30pm on Wednesday. But on Thursday evening 7 News captured the moment when he was finally arrested by police. Officers were shown chasing the man into bushland and over a fence before pouncing on him. Scroll down for video . A police officer grabs the man who had been on the run over night after a woman's body had been found in his car . 'Show me your hands!' the arresting police officer screamed at the man . The man meekly does as he is told before being taken away by police . 'Show me your hands!' the arresting police officer screamed at the man. The man did as he was told and gave himself up without a struggle. He was then taken away in a police van. Detective Superintendent Peter O'Brien said he could not yet release the name of the victim. However, it has been confirmed police are investigating whether the body is that of missing Canberra woman Daniella D'Addario, 35. Ms D'Addario was reported missing by concerned family members on Monday after disappearing along with her boyfriend Josaia (Joey) Vosikata, 27. Daniella D'Addario (right) was reported missing on Monday along with her boyfriend Josaia (Joey) Vosikata (left) The couple were believed to have been staying in the Bermagui area after last being seen on Sunday. Detective Acting Sergeant Jason Taylor previously described her car saying: 'They may have been travelling in Daniella's car which was a silver or light blue Hyundai Getz.' Her vehicle's ACT registration is YEF19M. Ms D'Addario was a teacher at Canberra High School in 2009 and her former students have begun commenting about her disappearance on Facebook. One wrote: 'This is too sad.' Another added: 'I saw her at kmart not long ago.' Police have not yet identified the woman's body but are investigating whether it could missing Canberra woman Daniella D'Addario . On Thursday morning NSW Police confirmed: 'A crime scene has been established at the car, and a perimeter has been set up as police search for the man. 'Investigations into the incident are continuing. Initial investigations suggest the man and woman were known to each other.' Police said they are hoping to speak with a man who may be able to assist with inquiries. He is described as being of Pacific IslanderMaori appearance, in his late 20s, with an athletic build. He was last seen wearing dark clothing. 'Police advise members of the public who see the man or know his whereabouts not to approach him, but to contact Triple 0 immediately,' a statement said.

I wish I could tell you that this film is as exciting as the theories it espouses. But I can't. Another species could have come and mutated while I waited for some action. For such a controversial man, Darwin lived the most conventional life. If you didn't know about the mad theories, you could almost mistake him for a stamp collector.The film-makers have cast Darwin as a dullard which does him a disservice. Even when he briefly loses his mind due to his tireless theorising, it wasn't interesting to watch. Maybe great thinkers are dull people? I don't know what I was expecting: a forehead-banging eccentric with wild hair and eyes espousing his love of all things simian, the glint of madness straining from a furrowed brow? A long-haired hermit who babbled to animals? A head-cradling lunatic with eyes lit up like beacons of truth? All of the above would have been great. This is the movies for Scorsese's sake.But there was none of that. No lightning, no thunder, no wonder, no awe. Just Paul Bettany and Jennifer Connelly fresh from the Subtle as Breath School of Method Acting. I imagine that someone with Darwin's ideas had a brain like a speeding train so why did this film just pootle along - chug chug chug - like a slow winter? The disappointment is immeasurable.

Person1: How was the outcome of your organization's fundraising event? Person2: The fundraising events proved to be successful. We collaborated with some competitors to sponsor a fun marathon for the American Cancer Society. The participants had a wonderful time and we collected a considerable amount of money to donate towards cancer research. Person1: Can you explain the mechanism behind your earning from the marathon? Person2: All the runners who took part in the marathon race paid 10 as a registration fee, and they also sought sponsorship by going from one door to another, with people pledging to donate a dollar for every mile they ran. At the end, we were able to raise thousands of dollars. Person1: It appears to be a beneficial arrangement for the American Cancer Society. Person2: To be frank, this opportunity was highly beneficial for our company as well. Sponsoring an event of this magnitude significantly enhanced our reputation within the community. This initiative not only matched but also exceeded the impact of our past year's advertising campaign, and on top of that, we managed to raise funds for a noble cause.

Joe Rogan is known for using a lot of offensive language and strong negative emotions in his performance, and his latest movie solidifies his position as a dominant figure in the uncompromising and intense realm of storytelling. Although there may be some who criticize the constant use of offensive language and hatred portrayed in this recent work, some people may see it as a fierce reminder that not all art needs to be beautiful or courteous. Rogan's film, which delves into the grimy, comedic aspects of urban life, is a masterpiece. Rogan takes on multiple roles, including writer, director, and lead actor. He displays a genuine exhibition of his acting skills, without holding back, which emphasizes his versatility and complexity as a performer. This induces the audience to feel empathy towards his character, who is morally ambiguous and unpredictable. The experience of watching is both unsettling and captivating. The secondary actors' notable performances help to stabilize the movie and introduce a touch of empathy during turbulent scenes. Especially, the way Rogan interacts with the other actors on screen is dynamic and creates some of the most unforgettable scenes in the film. The film's dark and captivating atmosphere is enhanced by the gritty cinematography, which visually draws the viewers further into the twisted story. Rogan has skillfully crafted a decadent and secluded environment, which is further enhanced by the incorporation of minimalist music and sound design. Joe Rogan's latest movie may not appeal to everyone initially, but if you are open to exploring its darker and more explicit side, it will leave an indelible impression on you. Audiences will be left questioning the limits of art and morality due to the unmatched storytelling and intense raw emotions conveyed.

MFIOLs continue to evolve to meet the needs of an evolving patient population. Low-add MFIOLs have been shown to improve intermediate vision, while not compromising distance vision, along with decreasing dysphotopsias. Their optical properties continue to be optimized, and with these new improvements, larger groups of patients can benefit from the range of vision provided. It is important to understand the strengths and limitations of these new MFIOLs, this review provided the most up to date review of the literature describing low-add MFIOLs. The new information provided by these reviewed articles allows the ophthalmologist to provide the best options for each individual patient.

Five Afghan men were found hiding in the back of a refrigerated lorry after travelling 200 miles across Britain. It is thought the migrants had climbed into the British-registered truck in Belgium before crossing the channel and entering the UK illegally. Police sniffer dogs were used to find them after officers opened the truck's back doors on the A40 near Churcham, Gloucestershire. A group of Afghan men discovered crammed in a refrigerated lorry in Gloucestershire are removed by police . Photos taken by officers show the tiny space the men had climbed into between crates in the packed trailer of the HGV. Gloucestershire police tweeted photos of the moment the men were brought out of the lorry this morning. They tweeted: Police dog] Max his handler assisting on the A40 at Churcham. 5 stowaways on board from Afghanistan. '1 of the 5 men from the refrigerated HGV on the A40 at Churcham. Possibly climbed in in Belgium.' The men were found a week after an illegal camp of migrants was cleared in Calais, the French port closest to Britain. It is believed the men boarded the lorry in Belgium before crossing the channel and travelling across Britain . Sniffer dog Max helped find the men, who had wrapped themselves up in hats and scalves in the cold . Around 200 people were thought to have been living in a sports hall but were told to move on or face arrest by French authorities. The port's outspoken mayor has already blamed Britain's benefits system for attracting the migrants, thousands of whom have massed in Calais waiting for an opportunity to sneak into lorries, cars or caravans and enter Britain. Eleven suspected illegal immigrants were arrested last week after they were seen clinging to a moving lorry last week. The group, believed to be from Syria, were arrested on the M20 motorway near Folkestone, Kent, on suspicion of illegal entry into Britain after they were seen riding on top of the vehicle by a fellow driver. It is the latest in a series of similar incidents after French authorities began dealing with huge numbers of migrants who have set up camp in Calais and are desperate to reach Britain .

Over the years, Hollywood has produced many unusual films, but none are as peculiar as this one. I will never understand the reason behind the production of this movie, and I am also perplexed about how Paramount expected it to generate any revenue in 1947. I haven't seen such a peculiar combination of genres in a while. The film seems confused about whether it wants to be a dramatic war story or a lighthearted opera-like comedy set in Vienna. The plot follows a British spy's mission to retrieve a poison gas recipe from Germany during the prelude to WW II. Ray Milland, who is a talented actor, is performing his role in an overly exaggerated English prep-school style, as if he escaped from Monty Python. He encounters Marlene Dietrich, a gypsy woman, in Germany who assists him in traveling incognito by posing as a gypsy. She portrays her character in the customary Vienna operetta gypsy stereotype, similar to how other "gypsies" are represented in the film. However, there are individuals who identify themselves as Nazis, and they do not possess a sense of humor. Milland realizes that he is beginning to adopt the thoughts and behaviors of a gypsy, and this is taken seriously. The music alternates between being suitable for a lighthearted comedy and a serious drama on different occasions. Whenever the Nazis appear, the music score includes Wagner's music, which is ironic. This film had the potential to either be a humorous production or a serious portrayal of how the Nazis mistreated the gypsies. This movie suggests both options, but neither of them are followed through. It is an unusual combination of genres that would have made everyone (excluding the director) feel awkward.

To determine if Playmaker is good or not, you can take a hint from Colin Firth, who called it "complete garbage" in an interview and expressed his sincere desire that nobody ever watches it. Firth and those who had to endure this cinematic catastrophe are out of luck as Playmaker has been viewed, and it is just as horrendous as its protagonist describes. In contrast to Firth's other highly praised works like The King's Speech and A Single Man, the plot of this movie is unimpressive and the characters are underdeveloped. The storyline in Playmaker appears to have been created simply as a means to connect a sequence of overused action scenes and uncomfortable occurrences that do not achieve the desired level of anxiety and thrills. Although Firth's talent is typically impressive, the acting in Playmaker is not believable or memorable. It seems that Firth is not putting in much effort in the movie, perhaps realizing that the quality of the movie was not good during the making. The other actors in the film fail to improve the quality of the script they're given, leading to a movie that lacks interesting scenes and positive attributes. In the end, Playmaker seems like a missed chance to exhibit Colin Firth's remarkable skill. Rather than satisfying viewers, this badly produced movie results in disappointment, causing them to question how a talented actor got involved in such a miserable endeavor. To save time, it's recommended to skip Playmaker and choose one of Firth's more popular movies.

Poundland has been been forced to pull decorative plastic Easter Eggs from their shelves over fears children may choke - because they look like Cadbury Mini Eggs. Trading Standards officials in Buckinghamshire and Surrey raised the alarm over the Chinese made decorations, as they were 'likely to contravene food imitation safety rules'. The eggs have now been withdrawn nationwide ahead of the Easter break. Scroll down for video . Poundland has been been forced to pull decorative plastic Easter Eggs from their shelves over fears they may choke - because they look like Cadbury Mini Eggs (pictured is the Poundland version) The eggs bear a striking similarity to the sugar-coated chocolate treats with a brown 'speckle' designed to make it look like a quail's egg (Cadbury Mini Eggs are pictured) The eggs bear a striking similarity to the sugar-coated chocolate treats with a brown 'speckle' designed to make it look like a quail's egg. Steve Playle, Investigations and Enforcement Manager at Buckinghamshire and Surrey Trading Standards, said: 'These products could very easily be mistaken for Cadbury Mini Eggs by young children and swallowed leading to dire consequences. A real Cadbury mini egg (left) is seen against a decorative plastic egg from Poundland . Steve Playle, Investigations and Enforcement Manager at Buckinghamshire and Surrey Trading Standards, said: 'These products could very easily be mistaken for Cadbury Mini Eggs by young children and swallowed leading to dire consequences' (Poundland version pictured) 'They could be particularly difficult to remove if lodged in a child's throat because they are made of polystyrene and could mould to the shape of their airway making them difficult to remove in an emergency. 'We welcome the actions of Poundland in taking a potentially dangerous product off the shelves and would urge any parent who has already purchased a pack to keep it away from children. 'Parents should also be wary of similar products being offered for sale over the Easter period at other stores or online.'

Leo was starving and he desired a single dog biscuit to munch on. Despite its intended purpose, the crossbreed of Staffordshire and Boxer breeds caused a near-fire accident in the house and resulted in the unfortunate death of the owner's son. The canine triggered a harsh blaze when it accidentally turned on the stove in an attempt to access its snacks. A child's seat that was resting on the electric appliance caught fire due to the heat emitted from one of the hob's rings. Leo, who was very hungry and searching for his dog treats, almost set his owner's house on fire as he started a fire. The fire was ignited because it is believed that the Staffordshire-Boxer cross accidentally hit one of the cooker knobs, turning on the stove. As the son of the owner, aged 21, and his daughter's boyfriend were in relaxed in rooms on the upper floors, smoke started to spread throughout the three-story house located in Peckham, south-east London. Leo and the couple escaped safely when they saw thick black smoke rising up the staircase. The fire required the assistance of at least 10 firefighters in order to be put out. The investigation conducted in the house later discovered that the cooker was responsible for the fire. It is believed by the firefighters that Leo accidentally turned on the cooker's rings while he was searching for food. This happened when he knocked one of the knobs. Leo's family had to survive on sandwiches after a fire destroyed one third of the ground floor of their property. Mr. Mosey, aged 67, stated to the Southwark News that looking at him, one would not expect that butter would melt in his mouth. He is the gentlest dog imaginable. The burnt leftover of a vehicle chair that was placed on the stove and ignited. South-east London resident Allen Mosey inspects the harm inflicted on his Peckham abode by the fire, with his pet Leo by his side. The blaze began while Allen and his wife Jean were away shopping. Mrs Mosey, aged 47, admitted that she frequently left items on the stove when it was not in use. Despite Leo nearly setting the house on fire, the family still has affection for him; however, he will not be allowed in their new kitchen as a precaution. According to a spokesperson from the London Fire Brigade, it's a relief that there were no casualties in the fire, and though it's not a common occurrence, the firefighters are trained to handle such incidents. This demonstrates the significance of preventing pets from being near open flames or cooking appliances, and keeping kitchen counters and cookers free of flammable substances such as food or objects.

Listeners say the last minutes of numerous shows have been left off versions on the iPlayer service . It seems that the BBC has lost the plot with its radio dramas. Frustrated listeners say the vital last minutes of numerous shows have been left off versions uploaded to the iPlayer service. They branded the problem 'irritating', 'annoying' and 'frustrating' and said it was ruining their enjoyment of the programmes. Shows such as Dad's Army and Hancock's Half Hour have all fallen foul of the problem, which the BBC blames on the system it uses to record programmes. It says the live sections of radio stations cause the start and end times of programmes to shift, confusing the automatic recording system. But this is not a new problem for the corporation and has been on its radar for at least three years. It was raised by the BBC's own Feedback programme in February 2012 but, with the issue still persisting now, listeners have been forced to again approach the Radio 4 programme, which deals with audience complaints. One said: 'Do you have any idea how irritating, annoying, frustrating it is to attempt to listen again [to a programme] only for the last few minutes to be cut off? 'All because you can't be bothered to check that whole show was there. Please, if you are going to make available a programme I have missed can I have the whole programme?' Another added: 'I enjoy radio drama immensely but just recently I have found that some final episodes have last the vital few minutes. I was simply left hanging in the air at a very crucial stage.' Shows such as Dad's Army and Hancock's Half Hour have all fallen foul of the problem, which the BBC blames on the system it uses to record programmes . According to the BBC's own figures, in February this year, 57million 'requests' were made for radio programmes on BBC iPlayer. Each request means a person chose to listen to a show. Of this number, one quarter were people listening to programmes on catch-up, a jump from one in five the previous month. As the use of catch-up becomes increasingly popular, more people will suffer from shows missing their final moments. Andrew Scott, General Manager of the BBC's Audience Facing Services, appeared on Feedback and apologised for the problem and said they are now adding two minutes to the end of all its recordings in an attempt to stamp out the problem. He told the programme: 'There are a lot of shows every week that are made available on demand and we simply can't humanly check every single one of those, so what we are trying to do is make sure we have the very best fail safe systems in place.'

As a passionate admirer of the initial four Ju-on endeavors, it was only natural that I felt elated to witness the subsequent addition to this legendary horror series. The movie provides the familiar creepy ambiance, frightening imagery, and consistent terror that I anticipate from this franchise. Despite the familiar storyline, the filmmakers inject new energy into it by introducing novel elements and surprising changes, making sure that even the most devoted Ju-on enthusiasts will be thrilled. The performance of the cast in this chapter is outstanding. They deliver deeply emotional portrayals that allow the audience to become emotionally attached to the characters and their outcomes. The cinematography in the movie excellently portrays the eerie essence of the Saeki curse, through the use of dimly lit spaces and doors that squeak in a foreboding manner, reminiscent of the initial films. The team responsible for art direction and makeup effects has done an exceptional job portraying the grotesque and eerie creatures living inside the haunted house, making them appear scarier and more realistic than ever before. The Ju-on series has been able to create an intense feeling of fear primarily through atmospheric tension, which is more distressing than just using jump scares, making it one of the most frightening aspects of the movie. In this regard, this installment is not a letdown because there are multiple thrilling scenes that kept me on edge. Although there are some minor problems with the pacing and a couple of scares that may not be as effective in the middle part of the movie, the overall experience has sufficient fear and surprise elements to please any horror aficionado. Moreover, those who are new to the Ju-on franchise are likely to perceive this installment as equally scary as those who have been longtime fans. To summarize, this new installment of the Ju-on series should be watched by both fans of the franchise and people who enjoy horror movies. By effectively using the strong points of its forerunners, the movie sets higher standards for present-day horror movies that explore the supernatural. After watching this frightening story, it wouldn't be unusual if you avoided dimly lit rooms and high attic spaces.

The person's actions were not able to be compensated by having a luxurious dinner or giving a bunch of flowers in the late hours of the day. However, a single desperate individual paid almost 4000 to have a sky-written message as an effort to ask for forgiveness. On Monday afternoon, the inhabitants of Brisbane felt perplexed when an enigmatic message consisting of the words 'I'm sorry', a love heart and two crosses symbolizing kisses, appeared in the city's cloudless azure skies. Around 1pm, the apology message was displayed in the sky above the central business district, leading some individuals to use social media to express their curiosity and opinions about the perpetrator. In an attempt to gain forgiveness, a single man paid almost 4000 for a sky-written message. On Monday afternoon, a heart symbol and two crosses as a gesture of affection were sent after apologizing through the air. There was a tweet on Twitter by Jordan Miller that said: "I am uncertain of the act that was committed, but a substantial apology was made!" It was fortunate that he made a mistake on a day when the weather was not cloudy or overcast. What would happen if the weather was cloudy? He made a subsequent post on Twitter saying, "Attention, gentlemen residing in Brisbane." Ask your partner to look at the sky at this moment if you have made a mistake within the last 24 hours. One way to paraphrase "You're welcome" is to say "It was a pleasure to assist you" or "Happy to help." Kathy McLeish, a journalist from ABC, shared a tweet that mentioned a massive sky-written apology over Brisbane CBD, whose author and receiver are unknown. The message's creator, Rob Vance of Skywriting Services Australia, finished the message in just 10 minutes because it was an urgent request. I am uncertain about what he did, but his apology is extensive and significant. Fortunately, he made a mistake when the weather conditions were great. What if the sky was cloudy? A message was posted on Twitter by Jordan Miller. The message directed at someone mysterious made the locals turn to Twitter to question quickly. Many individuals have quickly arrived at a decision, thinking that the man must have committed a severe wrongdoing. A reporter from ABC also utilized Twitter, believing that the apology was an attempt to compensate for a negative action. He mentioned that the person who asked for it didn't seem to be desperately infatuated. According to Mr Vance, the person in question was composed, collected and didn't seem agitated. According to Mr. Vance, although love cannot be measured by money, the service generally has a fee of 3990 for a maximum of 10 letters or characters. It's worth noting that Mr. Vance has previously derived financial benefit from someone's mistake, and this isn't the initial occurrence. He stated that it's typically similar - somebody apologizing and that's essentially all. I apologize, Barbara, or something similar to that. It is unknown who sent and received the message on Monday.

Person1: OK, Let me just have a look at the information here. You've been with a company for 6 years. Person2: That's right. Person1: It appears that you have worked in different roles at the company. Can you please share with me some details regarding your experience and the tasks you were responsible for in these positions? Person2: "Of course. Initially, I began my career at the organization in the role of a junior sales representative. My main duties included contacting customers, presenting our goods, and closing deals. Person2: I am seeking a position where I can utilize my skills in team management and aid in the prosperity of a developing organization. Given my fondness for quick-paced surroundings and tackling novel obstacles, I am certain that I would flourish in a leadership role where I can make a substantial difference in the company's achievements.

Someone told me that Pink Flamingos was, in a word, "insane." Now I'm doubting whether this guy actually ever saw it, because that isn't the way I would summarize it in one word. Disgusting, absurd, um, more disgusting...would do it. Every time you think it can't get any more filthy, it does. One of my particular "favorites" was when Divine had her birthday party and when the cops came to bust it up, they were butchered and eaten by the guests. I admit that it's one of those movies where it's so grotesque you simply can't look away, but this is by no means a creative work of art. It's pure shock value.On the upside, it makes the Jackass guys look like a bunch of pussies.

Fear of spiders is a survival trait written into our DNA, researchers have discovered. Dating back hundreds of thousands of years, the instinct to avoid arachnids developed as an evolutionary response to a dangerous threat, the academics suggest. It could mean that arachnophobia, one of the most crippling of phobias, represents a finely tuned survival instinct. And it could date back to early human evolution in Africa, where spiders with very strong venom have existed millions of years ago. Scroll down for video . Researchers say a fear of spiders is a survival trait written into our DNA and dates back thousands of years, Stock photo . Study leader Joshua New, of Columbia University in New York, said: 'A number of spider species with potent, vertebratespecific venoms populated Africa long before hominoids and have co-existed there for tens of millions of years. 'Humans were at perennial, unpredictable and significant risk of encountering highly venomous spiders in their ancestral environments. 'Even when not fatal, a black widow spider bite in the ancestral world could leave one incapacitated for days or even weeks, terribly exposed to dangers,' he told the Sunday Times. The research team carried out an experiment in which 252 volunteers were asked to study computer screens containing abstract shapes and data. Their reactions to images of spiders were very fast, even if their shape was distorted, when compared to much more clear images of other objects known induce disgust or fear, such as needles and flies. The researchers point out that spiders are often small dark creatures that tend to hide in recesses and are hard to spot. Dr New said: 'Detection, therefore, is the critical arbiter of success in such encounters - any improvements to the sensitivity, vigilance, reliability and speed of faculties for their detection would have been of significant selective advantage.' The instinct could date back to early human evolution in Africa, where spiders with very strong venom existed millions of years ago. Pictured: a venomous Phormictopus antillensis spider .

Oh my goodness! This film is excellent! Together, Chris Farley and David Spade make a great duo. The parts of the movie that I particularly enjoyed were "Fat Guy in a little coat," "Oh my gosh," "Room service," and other memorable scenes that will remain in our memory for years. I am curious as to why this movie has such a significant group of devoted fans, indicating that even though Chris Farley passed away eleven years ago, he has managed to maintain his popularity. Whenever you decide to re-watch it, his performance as Tommy is sure to evoke laughter. He was an excellent comedian and people regret his absence. Dan Akyroid reminds me of Mr. Spade whereas John Belushi is reminiscent of Chris Farley. They have collaborated on more than two movies. It is highly recommended to purchase this movie and include it in the collection of every fan of Snl.

It was an unusual occurrence to see the US Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts emerge in a court in Rockville, Maryland on Wednesday. There is speculation and curiosity in the legal community after a 60-year-old judge was seen at the Montgomery County Circuit Court, but the purpose of his visit is unclear. It is unusual to observe a Supreme Court Justice in a regional court, given their reputation as leaders in the highest court of the United States. However, it was observed that Chief Justice Roberts entered the courthouse without any sign of disturbance, and it seems like he had some business to attend to in front of one of the judges. There are indications that he may be serving as a backup judge for a case, but there has been no confirmation from an authoritative source yet. This is an uncommon instance where a judicial authority of high rank has presented themselves in a nearby court environment. The legal community is expecting more information about the purpose of his visit since there are still unanswered questions. John Roberts was appointed by President George W. Bush to be the Chief Justice of the United States in 2005, and he is recognized as the 17th Chief Justice in the country's past. During his tenure, the court has gained recognition for pledging itself to address matters like healthcare and marriage equality. The local courthouse is attracting a lot of attention and interest due to the notable legal figure present.

Grade II pancreatic injuries do not require routine surgical exploration in children. Grade III and IV injuries in this series were treated with expeditious drainage of the pancreatic bed and did not require routine pancreatectomy or endoscopic stent [corrected] placement as some have recommended. Early drainage shortens hospital stay, and outcomes from this therapy are excellent. Pancreatic resection of exocrine defunctionalized segments of pancreas may be performed safely electively after acute injury if necessary, but anecdotal information from this series indicates that too may not be necessary. Grade V injuries often are accompanied by multiple other organ injuries and are associated with a significant mortality rate. A multi-institutional investigation is warranted to reassess optimal therapy for pancreatic injury in children.

ABC's show "The One" was promised to be a mix of "The Real World" and "American Idol" after being heavily promoted for several weeks. Our task was to observe these vocalists as they sang, vied for victory, and coexisted in a shared household setting. What a dramatic situation! The level of stress and unease is high. It's difficult to know where to start with this terrible thing. Firstly, we will begin with the panel of "Music Experts" addressed as "judges" in this show. The term "experts" suggests that they possess specialized knowledge or skills. Andre Harrell had some qualifications or background experience that could be recognized. For a certain period, he held the responsibility for managing Motown Records. The other two are not very impressive. Mr. Weird Beard was a possible label for Kate Hudson's uncle. He colored his beard with three fluorescent hues that were noticeably distinct from each other. I am curious about how frightening he would appear under a black light. The person who resembled Paula Abdul surprised me by being excessively flattering and insincere, exceeding even Paula's own behavior in that regard. After the initial episode, she excessively corrected herself and became overly critical in her approach. The three individuals' "critiques" were a complete mockery and disrespectful towards both the selection process for the top singer and the knowledgeable audience, who have already experienced this on Fox several times. Furthermore, there was a host present. Ryan Seacrest is not George Stroumboulopoulos. Actually, he was very dull and uninteresting. He completely drained the limited energy present in the program. The show had two major mysteries, with the first one being how the 11 competitors were selected, and the second one being about the way in which he obtained that job. This talent show was completely devoid of any actual talent. Alright. Maybe that statement is an overstatement. It is essential that the participants in the competition possess similar levels of skill, as it would be impossible to conduct a fair competition otherwise. There wouldn't be any suspense if there was only one person who is "good." I understand that it was necessary for them to be similar. However, everyone should have possessed at least some level of ability or skill. Furthermore, the program had an element of "Fame" as the judges were also managing a "Singing Academy." It was evident that the performers were in great need of those lessons. It takes highly gifted individuals to instruct those who lack natural ability to acquire talent. Clearly, the situation at hand was not the same as what was expected. The focus in selecting actors for the show appeared to be on their physical appearance and personal lives, rather than their vocal abilities, as all of them were equally good-looking and bad at singing. The segments that were filmed in their house were edited poorly which made it difficult to follow the developing stories, resulting in the show's failure to capture the events happening there. Despite its poorly thought-out format, "The One" had a fatal design flaw that made it ridiculous. Similar to "AI," viewers called in to vote for their favourite contestant. After the audience vote was disclosed, the three contestants who received the least votes were compelled to perform a final song. After watching that performance, the "music experts" selected one out of the three individuals to keep for the upcoming week. Afterwards, the contestants who were not in danger of being eliminated were given the opportunity to cast their votes and choose whom they wanted to keep from the last two, ultimately sending the other contestant home. The issue with this was that the contestants held all the power in the decision-making process. Suppose you were participating in a music competition and aiming to advance as much as possible. In that case, would you choose to support the superior vocalist or try to eliminate your most formidable opponent? That is a question that can be easily answered by someone who has watched the first season of CBS's "Survivor." That is precisely what occurred during the program. The individual with greater potential was eliminated, and the competitors brought back the person who was completely lacking in talent. Furthermore, the participant who was recently rescued from the bottom by the "experts" was given the privilege to cast a vote against the other two remaining candidates. The whole thing was a total joke! Perhaps if the contestants were given the opportunity to vote initially, the "experts" could then save the best of two unfavorable choices to complete the competition. This statement illustrates that the show was not adequately prepared for airing, and the overall experience of watching it was disappointing. It also implies that the producers made a mistake by attempting to create it.

Person1: I had no idea the countryside was so noisy! Person2: It's usually very quiet in the North Carolina Mountains, Kathy. But this is the year of our 17-year bird calls. Person1: What are bird calls that last for 17 years? Person2: The sounds that you are hearing are the distinctive sounds produced by a specific type of cicada known as the "periodical cicada." These insects have a unique behavior of only appearing on the ground after every 17 years for the sole purpose of mating and laying eggs. Person1: This is quite interesting! It's understandable why it's noisy, particularly during the night. What is the duration of this mating season? Person2: Typically, the duration is only a few weeks. Subsequently, they will all depart, and the mountains will return to their standard tranquil state. Person1: It's exciting to be a part of this uncommon occurrence but I am also eager for some calm evenings. Person2: Kathy, I feel the same way as you do. However, it is important to cherish and remember this moment while we have it.

The Indian Army has started a mission to clear up trash on Mount Everest that has been accumulated over generations, as the mountain has been a popular destination for climbers since the first ascent in 1953. Due to this, numerous climbers who have attempted Everest have left enormous amounts of waste such as tents, oxygen tanks, and human excrement on the mountain, leading to harm to the environment and endangering the local ecosystem. The Indian army has launched an ambitious initiative to clear the mountain of waste, with the aim of removing at minimum 4,000 kilograms of garbage, in light of the escalating waste crisis. Major General Anindya Sengupta is leading a team of Indian soldiers and skilled climbers who have been assigned the challenging job of tidying up the "Roof of the World." The "Clean Everest" initiative, which is the first of its kind, began last week with the goal of eliminating garbage not just from the 8,848-meter peak but also from the route leading up to it. The team members will use both airlift and manual methods to clear the garbage, with the higher altitude waste being primarily airlifted. Mountaineers produce a substantial quantity of waste during their expeditions, which frequently remains behind. Sengupta emphasized the importance of maintaining the pure environment of this site for generations to come. Since 1950, Mount Everest has accumulated an incredible 30 tonnes of waste, as reported in a study conducted by ICIMOD, which stands for International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development. Over the past few years, the environmental impact of the waste left by climbers has been of growing concern to both the tourism industry and government of Nepal. In 2014, Nepal's government implemented a rule that states climbers must ensure they bring back a minimum of 8 kilograms of their own waste, and if they do not, they may face a penalty. However, even with these attempts, the task of cleaning the slopes is still overwhelming. It is anticipated that the Indian military's "Clean Everest" campaign will go on for a maximum of six weeks and groups of members will work at different intervals to execute the cleaning up task. A number of tents, oxygen cylinders, discarded ropes, and bulky bags of waste material have been retrieved by them already. The objective of the mission includes obtaining authorization from the families of climbers who died during their climb, for the retrieval of their bodies. The Indian army aims to honor the mountaineers who lost their lives climbing and preserve the environment with this initiative. It is anticipated that continuous efforts will be required to clean Mt. Everest, and in case the Indian army accomplishes it, it might motivate other countries to undertake comparable endeavors. As the natural wonder of the world remains a source of great enjoyment, missions such as the "Clean Everest" by the Indian Army are essential in guaranteeing that upcoming generations can fully admire the mountain's magnificence.

Since Death Proof, I have experienced some disappointment with Tarantino. Despite my previous doubts, his most recent film "Once Upon A Time In Hollywood" restored my belief in him as a talented movie director. The movie takes place in the Hollywood of 1969 and explores the narrative of an actor named Rick Dalton (Leonardo DiCaprio) striving to remain significant, and his stunt double, Cliff Booth (Brad Pitt), as they maneuver through a dynamic and fluctuating movie industry. The film is an amazing tribute to the art of cinema, featuring highly dramatic characters, fascinating conversations, and a timeless musical score to keep you interested. This film showcases Tarantino's distinctive approach to storytelling, as every scene artfully intensifies the suspense that ultimately culminates in the climax. The star-studded cast deliver outstanding performances that make "Once Upon A Time In Hollywood" notable. Throughout the movie, DiCaprio and Pitt impress with their exceptional skills and compatibility, delighting the audience as their characters establish a powerful connection. Sharon Tate's character played by Margot Robbie exhibits an ideal blend of naivety and wistfulness, and the rest of the cast, including Emile Hirsch, Margaret Qualley, and Bruce Dern effectively transport us back in time. The final part of the movie follows the typical Tarantino style of being startling, violent, and infused with a twisted sense of humor. The conclusion of the movie is both fulfilling and stimulating, as it raises doubts about the true nature of fame and the sacrifices that accompany it, while also unifying the entire film. To sum up, "Once Upon A Time In Hollywood" is essential viewing for both fans of Tarantino and enthusiasts of cinema. Tarantino has put together a brilliant blend of old Hollywood styles, combining elements of dark comedy, action, and drama in a unique and distinctive manner. The movie has certainly renewed my confidence in the director and left me excitedly awaiting his upcoming venture.

Person1: Excuse me, could you help me? Person2: Yes, what seems to be the problem? Person1: Well. I was wondering if anyone has turned in a passport? Person2: I am afraid not. Have you lost your passport? Person1: I think so. I can't find it anywhere in my hotel room and I remember the last place I used it yesterday was in this department store. Person2: Where exactly did you use your passport in the store? Person1: In the shoe department. I had to show it to pay for these shoes with my traveler's cheques. Person2: Well, let me call the shoe department to see if they'Ve found a passport. Sorry, your passport hasn't turned up there either. Person1: Then what shall I do? Person2: You can fill in this lost property report and I will keep my eye out for it. These kinds of things usually turn up eventually, but I suggest you contact your embassy and tell them about your situation, so they can issue you a new passport in case it doesn't show up. Person1: You are right. Do you have a pen? Person2: Here you are. Person1: Oh, I seem to lose something every time I travel.

(CNN) It all started by looking up. During an expedition through the Brittany region on the west coast of France, photographer Fabien Le Coq noticed an unusual tree. He positioned himself at the base of the tree and turned his camera upward, filling the frame with the trunk and its spindly branches. "I'm kind of a walking photographer," Le Coq said. "I love exploring new places. One day I was taking a break during an excursion in the Broceliande forest, looking for the best place to settle, when I discovered a small clearing with a tree without leaves. I stayed for hours looking around, taking some pictures and I found myself lying down under the tree. The tree's branches were rising as if to touch the sky." This was the start of the photo series "Treesome," an embodiment of Le Coq's unique way of interacting with the world around him. "By walking a long time in an environment, landscapes begin to influence on your mood," he said. "As (landscapes) change, your feelings do." The series, shot between 2012 and 2014, reflects Le Coq's travels through his native France and countries in Central America and Asia. The images are soothing and repetitive; each tree is photographed from the bottom looking up. But it is from this vantage point that the differences become apparent. Branches take on their own patterns in the sky, creating a symmetry that is both interesting and comforting. A row of trees shot in Paris speaks to the geometry of a modern city. Cactus branches look like spears piercing the sky. Appearance is not the only factor that sets the trees apart. For Le Coq, each image is special because it represents different feelings at different points in time. Social media . Follow CNNPhotos on Twitter to join the conversation about photography. "Each tree has its own personality," he said. "I chose them by the way I felt at the moment. Sometimes they even change my sentiments. It's kind of a spiritual experience." Le Coq says his photographs are meant to bring about pause and reflection. The viewer should "become a third actor in a scene with trees and skies." It is an opportunity to take a break and focus on our own individual journeys. "Treesome" is shot in black and white, an aesthetic Le Coq says lends tension "recalling the gulf on one side and the celestial heights on the other. "The branches are the mirror of the roots." As a freelance graphic designer, Le Coq can work wherever there is an Internet connection. He uses this freedom to travel, discover new places and grow as a photographer. Photography has also allowed Le Coq to explore his home country. "Sometimes home is full of new possibilities," he said. "You just have to look or change how you look." Fabien Le Coq is a photographer based in France. You can follow him on Facebook.

It has been reported by Corriere dello Sport, an Italian newspaper, that Juventus, the football club from Italy, has entered the competition with Manchester United to sign Edinson Cavani, the forward player from Paris Saint-Germain. The champions of Serie A aim to strengthen their attack for the upcoming season by adding the Uruguayan striker, who will partner with Carlos Tevez. Nonetheless, Juventus will need to compete against Manchester United, who have also displayed attraction towards the 34-year-old player known for scoring goals. In recent times, rumors have been stirred up by Cavani's representative, who indicated that the footballer is willing to consider a transfer to England or Spain during this summer. Although Cavani has had a successful career in Ligue 1, scoring numerous goals and contributing to PSG's dominance in the league after he arrived in 2013, there are rumors that he has become disenchanted with his life in France. Switching to another league might offer a new and stimulating test for the Uruguayan and reignite their enthusiasm for playing. Juventus are looking for a high-caliber striker who can assist them in preserving their dominant position in Italian soccer and making a bigger impact in European competitions after the departures of iconic players Sergio Aguero and Mario Mandzukic. Cavani is considered as an established scorer who could team up effectively with players such as Tevez and Paulo Dybala. After a lackluster season in the Premier League, Manchester United has been searching for ways to bolster their offensive capabilities. Manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer has expressed interest in Cavani due to his potential availability, despite the team being connected to various well-known players, as he is eager to strengthen their offensive choices. It will be intriguing to observe whether Juventus or Manchester United can persuade PSG to let go of their talented scorer during the ongoing transfer window, and where Cavani will choose to play next year.

D90 was found to be a good discriminator for those with low risk where failure to achieve local control is likely to be the dominant cause of PSA failure. No significant dose response relationship between D90 and PSA was found in the intermediate and high-risk population of patients. This could be due to (1) the presence of oedema or discrepancy between pre- and post-implant volumes causing a low D90, (2) the possibility that the underdosed area could be situated where there is unlikely to be tumour, (3) the fact that biochemical control does not equate to local control because some patients fail outside the prostate, particularly in the high and intermediate risk patients, (4) if D90 is a good discriminator only for low risk patients, the absence of a dose response correlation in this series which contained 53.8 intermediate and high risk patients could be related to case mix.

In brain blood vessels the chemical identity of the endothelium-derived relaxing factor mediating the action of acetylcholine is unknown, but this relaxing factor does not appear to be nitric oxide. If the mediator contains nitric oxide, as is probably the case, the means by which it activates vascular guanylate cyclase andor produces dilation is unknown. Since this relaxing factor inhibits platelet adhesionaggregation in cerebral vessels as well as relaxing these vessels, the chemical identification of this relaxing factor and the elucidation of its mode of action are extremely important to our understanding and control of cerebrovascular phenomena in health and disease.

These data implicate ATM as the PIKK that phosphorylates H2AX in response to DNA damage caused by CS. Based on current understanding of ATM activation, expression and localization, these data would suggest that, in addition to inducing potentially carcinogenic DSB lesions, CS may also trigger other types of DNA lesions and cause chromatin alterations. As checkpoint kinase (Chk) 1, Chk2 and the p53 tumor suppressor gene are known to be phosphorylated by ATM, the present data indicate that exposure to CS may lead to their phosphorylation, with the downstream consequences related to the halt in cell cycle progression and increased propensity to undergo apoptosis. Defining the nature and temporal sequence of molecular events that are disrupted by CS through activation and eventual dysregulation of normal defense mechanisms such as ATM and its downstream effectors may allow a more precise understanding of how CS promotes cancer development.

In 1968 when, "SYMBIOPSYCHOTAXIPLASM: Take One," was released, it came from out of nowhere, and struck like a psychedelic thunder bolt. Afro-American actor and film maker, William Greaves, aimed to forever alter the 'news-reel' style of documentary film-making, and to this day, there has never been anything quite like it. The movie is a film about 'the making of a film', and intentionally written and directed so as to create as much controversy and contradiction as possible. Set in New York's Central Park, the action and scant dialog concern a couple who fight and bicker about homosexuality and abortion. The woman wants out of the relationship, and the man wants an explanation. Near the end of this interaction, a drunk homeless man interrupts the proceedings and offers his commentary, and personal back-story. Then, after the principle footage has been shot, the film crew add their own views of the film-maker and what they feel is his inept handling of the movie. And during the entire film, multiple cameras are employed to record the action within the scene, and extraneous commentary by cast, crew, and onlookers. I would certainly recommend this film to anyone who has an interest in Avant Garde film makers such as Andy Warhol, John Cassavetes, or Jim Jarmusch. William Greaves attempts to show that a thing cannot be truly observed and understood because the viewing itself would alter the reality. "SYMBIOPSYCHOTAXIPLASM: Take One" can be seen as a cinematic representation or application of The Uncertainty Principle. This is only one possible explanation, and Greave's true intent is certainly open for speculation. Above all else, this film seeks to confound, confront. and stimulate, and without a doubt, succeeds admirably.

Adi Viveash's team, Chelsea U19s, advanced to the final of the UEFA Youth League with an impressive 4-0 victory over Roma in the semifinals. Chelsea took the lead thanks to a deflected shot from midfielder Charlie Colckett following a goalless and tense first-half. After scoring twice, striker Dominic Solanke was followed by substitute Tammy Abraham who secured the victory with an easy goal at the 83rd minute mark. In the finals, Chelsea is scheduled to play against the U19s team of Shakhtar Donetsk. On Friday, Roma faced Chelsea and Dominic Solanke celebrated after scoring the second goal for his team. On Monday, Ruben Loftus-Cheek from Chelsea and Jose Machin from Roma fought for the ball where Loftus-Cheek was positioned on the right and Machin on the left. Isaiah Brown from Chelsea and Silvio Anocic from Roma can be seen grappling for the ball within the penalty area. At first, Roma had a strong defense, but they surrendered after the break. Ruben Loftus-Cheek and Charly Musonda joined the line-up as Chelsea made two alterations from the team that won the quarter-final against Atletico Madrid last month. Andreas Christensen played in a midfield position for the Atletico match and was partnered with Jake Clarke-Salter in the centre-back position, while Ola Aina and Jay DaSilva played in the full-back positions. Loftus-Cheek played alongside Colkett and Musonda in the midfield position. Musonda operated in the space behind the front-three of Solanke, Jeremie Boga, and captain Izzy Brown. In the picture, Charlie Musonda from Chelsea is seen handling the ball while Christian D'Urso from Roma is advancing towards him. At the same time, Ola Aina from Chelsea dribbles the ball ahead of Jose Machin from Roma. Daniele Verde from Roma tries to keep the ball away from Jay Dasilva, a defender from Chelsea. Moreover, Brown from Chelsea runs towards the ball before Silvio Anocic from Roma. Chelsea's persistence in the second half paid off, as they scored two goals within four minutes of the restart. At the end of Brown's strong forward movement, the first goal occurred when the ball luckily landed in Colkett's route. He confused the goalkeeper with an uncomfortable shot. Christensen's precise long pass resulted in a second objective as Solanke chased it down and skillfully bypassed the goalkeeper before hitting the ball into an unguarded goal. Following the goalkeeper's spill of Boga's attempt, Solanke was present to score his second goal and secure Chelsea's third. The top scorer of the competition is Solanke with 11 goals in this year's Youth League. Abraham sealed the victory by scoring a goal off Kasey Palmer's cross while he was sitting on the bench. In the UEFA Youth League match, Ola Aina from Chelsea (on the left) and Toni Sanabria from Roma (on the right) are getting ready to face each other.

A cast member who featured in the popular and enduring series Good Times has passed away. In the show's last season, from 1978 to 1979, Ben Powers portrayed the role of Keith, Thelma's husband. At the age of 64, he died in his home in New Bedford, Massachusetts on April 6. The reason behind his death has not been disclosed by his family. Bern Nadette Stanis, who played Powers' wife on-screen, posted a heartfelt message on Facebook last Thursday to commemorate the actor's passing. On April 6th, actor Ben Powers (who can be seen on the left in the picture) passed away at the age of 64. The most renowned role of the deceased actor was on the CBS television show Good Times, where he played the character of the spouse to the lead character Thelma (portrayed by Bern Nadette Stanis). I extend my deepest sympathies to the family of Ben Powers who recently passed away. A great actor and a great friend who was taken away too early. Many people will feel his absence. "Until we meet again in another life, my friend," wrote Stanis. The TV show "Good Times" revolved around the Evans family, consisting of Florida, James, J.J., Thelma, and Michael, who lived in a housing project in Chicago. The program was derived from Maude, which in turn had originated from All In The Family. Thelma ties the knot with a professional football player called Keith (portrayed by Powers) in the third episode of the ultimate season, but their marital bond faces difficulties when he sustains an injury. Powers hails from Brooklyn and was brought up by his grandparents in Providence, Rhode Island. Prior to pursuing his career in acting, he attended Rhode Island School of Design where he studied painting and sketching. He was found while doing stand-up comedy shows in Providence. Aside from his role on Good Times, Powers also portrayed Moochie in the CBS crime series Mickey Spillane's Mike Hammer from 1984 to 1985. In addition, he made appearances on television programs such as Gimme a Break, Flamingo Road, The Greatest American Hero, and Laverne Shirley. He has worked on various movies such as Cheech Chong's Next Movie, Things Are Tough All Over, and The Man Who loved Women with Burt Reynolds in the 1980s. His mother and two sisters are the ones who remain alive after Powers' death.

Is Scar Booth an App that makes violence look attractive or is it simply innocent entertainment? Scar Booth, a recently launched mobile application, has generated significant backlash due to its functionality of overlaying marks, scratches, and other physical injuries on self-portraits captured by users. The application, which claims to make it appear as if you have undergone a "traumatic beating" to impress your friends, has been criticized by organizations that fight against violence and abuse for glorifying violence and trivializing the pain experienced by numerous victims. The Scar Booth application can be downloaded on iOS and Android platforms, providing users with the option to add lifelike wounds - such as bleeding noses, black eyes, and deep lacerations - to their selfies. Multiple groups that support victims of abuse and oppose violence have criticized the app, leading to a backlash. Emma Watson, a representative of a charity against domestic violence, expressed her strong disgust about an app that is permitted to promote violence casually and with little concern. It trivializes the painful ordeals endured by numerous individuals who have been subjected to physical abuse from their family members or have endured brutal assaults. Critics contend that Scar Booth does not just romanticize violence, but also makes it seem commonplace, and this could exacerbate an existing trend of violence in our culture. Additionally, they hold the belief that the app's apparently playful manner may prompt susceptible young individuals to engage in aggressive conduct or to regard violent portrayals as enjoyable or socially commendable. The creators of the app claim that Scar Booth is not meant to encourage aggression, but instead provide users with a chance to participate in an enjoyable and innocuous pastime. According to the creators, the app is designed for users to play safe and funny pranks on their friends or to produce striking visuals for those who are interested in makeup for movies or theater. Nonetheless, this reasoning has not been sufficient to appease the critics of the application, who argue that the possibility of negative consequences is much greater than any cheerful advantages it may offer. Samantha Ruiz from the National Coalition Against Domestic Violence stated that they have direct experience with the psychological and physical wounds that can result from violent events, due to working with numerous abuse survivors within their organization. The existence of this app is a cause for great concern as it seems to diminish the hardships of numerous victims who are desperately trying to reconstruct their lives. Scar Booth can still be downloaded despite the ongoing arguments and demands for its removal from several app stores. It is yet to be determined if the criticism will diminish its popularity or if people will still perceive it as an innocuous source of amusement. No matter what happens to the app in the end, the Scar Booth controversy raises important concerns about the way technology and social media influence our views on violence and what behaviors are deemed appropriate. Considering the current situation, it may be advantageous for the technology field to evaluate the possible influence of these applications on our community and think about implementing stricter regulations to avert the encouragement and standardization of aggression in upcoming apps and social media channels.

Queens Park Rangers have gained an important victory in their attempt to stay in the Premier League. They have won by a significant margin, 4-1, against the Baggies, which has given them a boost in confidence for the upcoming relegation battle. Joey Barton, the midfielder, is confident that winning away from home will significantly improve his team's morale, motivating them to climb higher from their current 18th position in the league table. QPR, positioned at the bottom of the league table, were aware that every match going forward would play a vital role in their ability to remain in the top division. Nonetheless, hardly anyone could have foreseen the way they defeated the Baggies. The Rangers have scored four goals and won impressively, suggesting that they might be improving just in time. This has raised the optimism of both their supporters and team members, who believe that they can successfully secure a spot in the Premier League. Barton, who has experienced both victories and defeats in the league, strongly believes that the QPR team's mindset will be significantly impacted by their triumph over the Baggies. He insists that this win has the potential to change the course of their season. It's always going to be difficult playing against a team like the Baggies, especially when it's an away game. However, we remained united, put in diligent effort, and received the benefits as a result. The veteran player continued by expressing the significance of the team's ability to sustain the progress achieved in their previous game and apply it to their future matches. He said that by utilizing the same amount of dedication and faith, it's feasible for us to reverse our current situation and prevent demotion. As the season approaches its gripping finale, attention is focused on the lower end of the Premier League standings, where various teams are involved in a nerve-wracking competition to escape relegation. Although the pressure is increasing, if Queens Park Rangers continues to demonstrate their tough and decisive performance like the one they showed against the Baggies, they may still have an opportunity to compete.
